turns.speaker: JENKINS
turns.text: We're all here, and ready sir!

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: Jenkins.  Can I get you some help?

turns.speaker: JENKINS
turns.text: Too late for that sir.  Give my love to the misses.  Get those bastards!

turns.speaker: JONATHAN
turns.text: Hello, Mrs. Webster.  Is China there?

turns.speaker: MRS WEBSTER
turns.text: She went to a waxwork party

turns.speaker: JONATHAN
turns.text: A party at a waxwork huh?

turns.speaker: MRS WEBSTER
turns.text: Can I give her a message?

turns.speaker: JONATHAN
turns.text: You don't happen to have the address do ya?

turns.speaker: JUNIOR
turns.text: I hope you enjoyed your visit.

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: Uh yes, thank you.  It was quite enjoyable.

turns.speaker: JUNIOR
turns.text: Two of your friends left earlier MARK Uh huh.

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: Haven't we been doing our homework.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I've always wondered why someone would believe in something like that.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Getting scared?  Don't worry, they've probably just gone home.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Wooo.  Jealously rearing its ugly head.

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: I'm not kidding.  I want to get out of here - now, ok.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Then why do you still like her?

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: Like her?  I don't know if I ever liked her.  It's just you want what you can't get.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I don't know.  I really like you and I think you're very attractive.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: No I'm serious.  It's. it's just I don't know I. I'm looking for something else.

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: No, no James, it's not like that.  Tony and China, they're just friends.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: That's not what you said last night.

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: Ok, so maybe I was a little over emotional.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: You aren't sick! We've got to get back.  What are you doing!

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: Listen Sarah, I think I know what's going on ok.  I went to the waxwork today.I met this man.

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: You don't understand.  I recognized his face now come on.

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: If my mother caught me up here she'd kill me.

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: Well.   .this, is Mr. Lincoln.  And that's the man I saw at the waxwork.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Well, it all started when a friend and I

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: I can't believe she went out with that monster last night

turns.speaker: TONY
turns.text: Forget her Mark, she's a bitch

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: Guys, if I'm going to play the hero at least give me a little room.

turns.speaker: TONY
turns.text: This time I really don't see anyone man.

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: Must be what we came for. The four stand slowly and enter through the doors, which close behind them.  They begin walking around  the WAXWORKS, which appear gruesome. The first they spy is of a high school student with a letter  jacket on the verge of being hacked with an axe by and angry woodsman.  They give each other looks of  disgust and continue on.  The next is of a Frankenstein-esque creature carrying a woman in its arms.  The  four are now roaming around the WAXWORKS individually, with TONY encountering what appears to be  a tribal INDIAN pointing a knife towards a victim.  MARK walks past a circus cart with some sort of werebeast inside, and then continues on to a staircase exhibit with a dead woman at the base of it.  On the  staircase is a zombie-fied creature.  We see CHINA walking on the other side of a bandage wrapped man  pumping gasoline into a woman's mouth.  Finally, we see TONY walking up to a cottage room display.

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: Sir Wilfred, this is Sarah Brighton.  This is Sir Wilfred.

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: No thank you sir we're fine.

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: Well, it's a long story.SIR WILFRED Oh good share.  I love them

turns.speaker: SIR WILFRED
turns.text: If you sold your soul to the devil, you'd never age either

turns.speaker: SIR WILFRED
turns.text: Any student of Black Magic can do it.   .most of these books will tell you how! SARAH So what happens when you've sold out?

turns.speaker: SIR WILFRED
turns.text: You get yourself a regular job, as Satan's disciple.

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: Doing what? SIR WILFRED Tipping the scales.  Ruining that delicate balance between good and evil.  I think  that our Mr. Lincoln has found a very effective way of doing it.  There's a  voodoo belief that by making a wax effigy of an evil being, containing a  belonging of his he possessed in earthly form, and feeding him the soul of a  believing victim, you can bring him back to life!

turns.speaker: SIR WILFRED
turns.text: Maybe before the event, never after.

turns.speaker: MARKS MOTHER
turns.text: Darling?  I hear you were having drinks with the butler the other night.  Now  you know that sort of thing leads to anarchy.

turns.speaker: MARKS MOTHER
turns.text: One has to keep the distance between `them' and `us'

turns.speaker: MARKS MOTHER
turns.text: Servants.  Oh isn't it terrible darling, two more people have disappeared

turns.speaker: MARKS MOTHER
turns.text: Don't be facetious darling. Now drink your milk, you're late for college

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: Mom, when are you going to let me have some coffee in the morning?

turns.speaker: MARKS MOTHER
turns.text: When - you're a big boy.  I mean you know it's bad for you

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: But mom, I NEED THE CAFFINE - BADLY

turns.speaker: MARKS MOTHER
turns.text: I'll think about it.  Now run along darling.

turns.speaker: TONY
turns.text: Oh! The virgin has spoken! SARAH Stop it!

turns.speaker: TONY
turns.text: Save it for the powder room babe, this man is in pain

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: You guys are being real assholes

turns.speaker: TONY
turns.text: You bet.  We all can't be such modern people

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Come on Mark MARK Ah hell, why not.  I'll get the maid to write the essays

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Looks a little spooky boys, you think we should do this?

turns.speaker: TONY
turns.text: Never fear, Tony is here.  Ladies first.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: I'll come back all the time.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: I'm just saying, you're going to be fine.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Mom, I'm sorry.  I wanted to tell you. But it never felt right.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: I think playing in a band called "Bitch" might put a dent in the whole "perfect family" thing.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Yes it is.  Can we please not do that? Please?  Cause it is.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: He loves you very much.  He just--

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: Listen to me.  The one thing in life that I definitely don't regret...is the choice. I made to be your mother.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: It got so bad your father almost had to put me away.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Someone crying.  A girl.  I thought I was crazy.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: Because he was worried about me.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: Yes.  I'm sure he's hoping you'll pack me full of prozac so he can live out his life in peace.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: Because, I don't know, because sometimes...sometimes I forget things...and ever since Caitlin left, ever since my daughter left for school, there've been...I fainted and...  Why is this so hard?

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: She finished my solitaire game and turned on the radio...she likes rock and roll. Angry rock and roll.

turns.speaker: DR. DRAYTON
turns.text: How do you know it's a she?

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: I saw her in the water.  Beside me.  She was filling the bathtub.

turns.speaker: DR. DRAYTON
turns.text: Do you have any idea who she is?

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: What do you think I should do?

turns.speaker: DR. DRAYTON
turns.text: Try to communicate with her somehow.

turns.speaker: DR. DRAYTON
turns.text: Can't hurt.  And I think it's important you find out what she wants.

turns.speaker: DR. DRAYTON
turns.text: I don't know.  My aunt used to use my uncle's old pajamas and a candle.

turns.speaker: DR. DRAYTON
turns.text: Well, that's what we're here for.

turns.speaker: DR. DRAYTON
turns.text: Whether you imagined it or not, you actually saw and heard things that frightened you...that gave you reason for concern.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: Isn't there something called group hysteria?

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: Maybe.  I don't know.  I just know that when all this was happening, I felt, some part of me felt...alive.  Like somebody needed me.  And the more I reached out to, it, the fuller it became.

turns.speaker: DR. DRAYTON
turns.text: You're saying you willed these events to happen?

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: I don't know, I'm very confused right now.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: She said, "You know."  That I know.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: I felt...pain.  That she'd been hurt by someone.  This is great.  I'm trying to intuit the emotions of a figment of my--

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: Me?  No.  Well, in the accident I was injured, but...

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: Last year.  I drove my car up a tree. Nothing serious, this...  ...a minor concussion.  But the car looked bad.  It could have been bad.  I think it scared the hell out of Norman.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: That he doesn't...see me, or, you know, that I'm...that's something's wrong...with me.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: No, it doesn't...Okay, look, I see what you're doing here, and that's, I'm sorry, but that's not it.  My marriage is fine. I've had some kind of "empty-nest" episode where I saw some things that weren't there.  Let's deal with that.  I'm willing to deal with that.  I just don't want to go conjuring problems where none exist.

turns.speaker: MRS. TEMPLETON
turns.text: Of course.  You must be so proud.

turns.speaker: MRS. TEMPLETON
turns.text: Everyone's very anxious to shake hands with our newest academic celebrity.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: Just fine.  It's a lovely party.

turns.speaker: MRS. TEMPLETON
turns.text: Norman was telling me the dream house is finally finished.

turns.speaker: MRS. TEMPLETON
turns.text: Wonderful.  It's good to see you two doing so well.

turns.speaker: MRS. TEMPLETON
turns.text: I know how hard it can be sometimes.

turns.speaker: MRS. TEMPLETON
turns.text: Well, I don't think I've seen you since the reception at Dean Ackerman's last year.

turns.speaker: MRS. TEMPLETON
turns.text: For the Dupont Chair.  I swear.  I'm becoming the nosy old lady I used to run from at Amherst.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: No.  I'm just not sure what you mean.

turns.speaker: MRS. TEMPLETON
turns.text: There was just...some tension.  You were upset.  I remember being concerned.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: Ohhh yes.  No, no.  Just a little, you know...We're fine.

turns.speaker: MRS. TEMPLETON
turns.text: Well, I'm glad.  Pardon my intrusiveness, but we do have to stick together you know.

turns.speaker: MR. FEUR
turns.text: I'm running late here.  I just came back for my briefcase.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: Right.  Well, I wanted to stop by to welcome you to the uh, to the neighborhood.  I'm Claire Spencer.  From next door.

turns.speaker: MR. FEUR
turns.text: This really isn't a good time.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: Give me that shit.  Your wife.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: It's Mrs...It's Claire...Spencer.  From next door.  Is everything--

turns.speaker: MRS. FEUR
turns.text: I've seen you.  From the window.

turns.speaker: MRS. FEUR
turns.text: He's so...it's too much...and I can't...I can't breath...

turns.speaker: MRS. FEUR
turns.text: And I'm afraid.  Oh god, I'm so afraid of...

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: What?  What are you afraid of?

turns.speaker: MRS. FEUR
turns.text: I can't, no, no, I can't...

turns.speaker: MRS. FEUR
turns.text: That I'll just...that one day I'll just...disappear.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: Tell me.  I can help you.

turns.speaker: MRS. FEUR
turns.text: How?  How can you help me?  With your flowers and your perfect life...

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: I know.  And I'm sorry.  I've been consumed with...my daughter left...for school.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: I'm sorry.  It's for the flowers.  Why don't you...

turns.speaker: MRS. FEUR
turns.text: Oh God.  He's back.  I'm sorry.  Please forget that I...I don't know what I'm saying.  Please...

turns.speaker: MRS. FEUR
turns.text: For scaring you like I did.  When I thought about what that must have seemed like that day...

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: Would you like some iced tea?

turns.speaker: MRS. FEUR
turns.text: And these roses.  They're much prettier up close.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: Of what?  What were you so afraid of?

turns.speaker: MRS. FEUR
turns.text: You're going to think I'm crazy or something.

turns.speaker: MRS. FEUR
turns.text: Have you ever felt so completely consumed by a feeling for someone that you couldn't breathe?  That the time together is so passionate and consuming that you felt physical pain when they would leave?

turns.speaker: MRS. FEUR
turns.text: I couldn't catch my breath.  That's not a metaphor, that's...And I panicked.  I never dreamed anyone would hear me back there...  I tried to leave him.  Went to my mother's in Boston.  He brought my things up and pleaded with me to come home.

turns.speaker: MRS. FEUR
turns.text: I'm sorry that I frightened you like that.  But I was so touched by your concern.  I've been lonely here.  Perhaps we could be friends.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: I'd like to talk to you about Madison.

turns.speaker: MRS. FRANK
turns.text: Just plain old coffee.  None of that mocha nonsense.

turns.speaker: MRS. FRANK
turns.text: You look a little old for a student.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: I'm not.  We...we met at a party.

turns.speaker: MRS. FRANK
turns.text: Sounds about right.  Never understood how a girl that wild got all A's.  Sure didn't get it from me.  They wanted to put her in a special school for the gifted when she was young.  Maddie wouldn't hear about it.

turns.speaker: MRS. FRANK
turns.text: Well she wouldn't.  He left when she was twelve.  Never spoke about him after that.

turns.speaker: MRS. FRANK
turns.text: It's like that.  Doesn't seem real.  No note.  Nothing.  Cops say she'll be back.  I just wanna know what happened.

turns.speaker: MRS. FRANK
turns.text: Full scholarships.  Princeton too.  She wanted to stay close.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: You must have been very proud.

turns.speaker: MRS. FRANK
turns.text: They're calling me in to work.

turns.speaker: MRS. FRANK
turns.text: Y'hear anything you'll let me know?

turns.speaker: MRS. FRANK
turns.text: Biology.  She wanted to be a doctor.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: He looked like one of the Monkees.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: ...just so she could cut them off.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: I came in from my room...

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: And there's this brilliant conductor in purple briefs with no bangs cursing his ass off in Finnish.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: You should have heard her play.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: We both auditioned for the Philharmonic. One cello position open.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: And I kicked ass.  My best stuff.  Then I stood in the hallway and listened to her audition...and I cried.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: I'm not.  Couldn't pick up my cello for weeks.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: She got it.  Turned it down.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: I met a dashing young grad student after a recital one night...

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: Why does everyone find that so surprising?

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Cause...your...only daughter just went away to school...who you were incredibly close with aaand I'd be tripping...

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: And so far my day has consisted of taking pictures of my roses for the garden club.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Wow.  Got here just in time.  I brought you this.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: It soothes heart-ache and promotes psychic wellness.  Sela suggested I bring--

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: You're discussing me with your psychic?

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: She's not a psychic.  Just a very enlightened spirit.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: So you'll have some later.  Notice anything...different?

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: Oh my god.  You bought it.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Beautiful thing, alimony.  Lose a husband, get a car.  Think it'll help me pick up dudes?

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Listen, I've gotta run.  I just thought I'd stop by and see if you want to take the boat out, say Thursday morning?

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: I don't know.  When you say it, it sounds crazy.  But what else could it all be?

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Just bought this beautiful antique Ouija.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: In the window.  Norman's at work.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: No, you're not.  But a presence in your house is not something to be taken lightly.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: Are we hoping the ghost is going to have to pee?

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Place your fingers on the planchette.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: We wish to commune with the spirit of Mrs. Feur.  What's her first name?

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: It's initials.  F is Feur.  It's her.
